Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Low-cost Detection and Enrichment of Nucleic Acids by Interfacing with Commercially Available Cell Sorters
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project will be to enable affordable detection and enrichment of rare DNA or RNA molecules from a large background population. Currently, such detection is performed on expensive, dedicated instruments that have low sensitivity and are not able to enrich. The proposed strategy is to encapsulate the fluorescently-identified target molecules in thin oil shells so that they mimic cells, and then process them on sensitive and high-throughput cell-sorting instruments that are readily available. By offloading the detection and enrichment to such machines, all that is required by researchers is a simple tool that encapsulates the molecules in thin oil shells. Applications afforded by high sensitivity and enrichment are numerous, from rare pathogen or cell detection to target capture of uncommon mutant sequences with the goal of downstream sequencing. Between the reduced cost and expansion of capabilities, this approach has the potential to become a widely adopted method.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to enable high-throughput digital PCR (dPCR) at a dramatic cost reduction by interfacing with existing flow cytometers (FC). The main research objectives center on characterizing and optimizing the dPCR droplets for use on a wide variety of FC instruments originally intended for cell sorting. First, the biological, chemical, mechanical, and optical properties of the dPCR droplets will be optimized to guarantee compatibility with different FC systems while maximizing earlier PCR efficiency and specificity. Next, serial dilutions of target sequences will be run to test and improve detection thresholds. Those same samples also will be benchmarked against currently commercially available dPCR systems. In tandem, the droplet-on-FC system will be used in a research collaboration to quantitate and characterize HIV latency in an infected cell population. Initial results with FC-processed droplets are promising, as FC systems are already remarkably flexible due to the range of cell types they must be capable of accepting.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Digital PCR (polymerase chain reaction) is the amplification and subsequent detection of individually compartmentalized pieces of DNA or RNA. Such separation allows infrequent targets to be seen against an otherwise overwhelming background and can be used, for example, to detect rare pathogens, measure heterogeneity in a population of cells, or count copies of genes. The highest throughput digital PCR systems contain reactions in 10-100 micron drops suspended in oil (a "single emulsion," Fig 1a). Current commercial systems that implement this simple strategy, however, require an expensive, single-purpose optical detector for droplet readout. In this Phase I SBIR grant, we set out and succeeded in developing a system for offloading the detection of drop-based PCR to commonly available flow cytometers. Those cell-analysis instruments benefit from wide adoption and decades of development spent on accuracy, high throughput, and multichannel detection. By making PCR-capable droplets that can be accommodated by flow cytometers as cells usually are, we will reduce the cost of digital PCR since a simple drop generation system is the only additional hardware needed. Moreover, many flow cytometers can sort in addition to performing optical analysis, thus offering a whole new ability of enriching target molecules for downstream sequencing. 

The interfacing of PCR with flow cytometers was accomplished by encapsulating the PCR reactions in thin oil shells that were suspended in an aqueous buffer (a "double emulsion," Fig 1b). The oil envelope mimics the membrane of a cell and so allows the drop emulsion to be processed as a cell suspension would be. With this strategy, we achieved several milestones. First, we were able in a single run to use a flow cytometer to detect and sort millions of PCR reactions in double emulsions. This arrangement had a sensitivity of one target molecule in almost a million and outperformed commercial digital PCR systems in a benchmarked comparison. At the same time, we showed that we could identify different target sequences simultaneously through multiplexing. A significant advantage of incorporating flow cytometers is the ability to sort detected target sequences (Fig 2), and we also demonstrated that we could both enrich one rare target while de-enriching a second, more common target. The final, relative enrichment was 10,000 fold.

Since flow cytometers are already available to many researchers, our proprietary system developed under this grant will enable low-cost digital PCR with high sensitivity and the unmatched ability to sort.
